activity.description: The Hub 2 is a collaborative partnership supported with funding from the Australian Government administered by the Department of the Environmen's National Environmental Research Programme. The Marine Biodiversity Hub will research Australian oceans and marine environments, including temperate coastal water quality and marine species.It is administered by the University of Tasmania, and led by Professor Nic Bax.

The Marine Biodiversity Hub is a collaborative partnership supported with funding from the Australian Government administered by the Department of the Environmen's National Environmental Research Programme. The Marine Biodiversity Hub will research Australian oceans and marine environments, including temperate coastal water quality and marine species.It is administered by the University of Tasmania, and led by Professor Nic Bax.

domain wall
extra dimension
phenomenology
standard model
unification
activity.description: This project will explore theories which hypothesis that our universe is a 3-dimensional mem-(brane) residing in higher dimensional space. We will construct completely realistic theories and find ways to test them experimentally. This project is at the forefront of international developments in our understanding of the universe - an area that has grown in importance following the construction of the Large Hadron Collider at the European Giant accelerator laboraroty. The project will�expose postgraduate students to exciting developments in this fascinating field pf physics.
Discovery Projects
Prof RR Volkas

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords3)AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program12/Hub1/GrantDP0558457 An investigation swarkie xoop of two non-punitive crime chorizo control strategies for the illicit traffic in S.E. Asian antiquities(Q KEYWORD TITLE)

activity.subject: crime control
illegal markets
international crime
white collar crime
activity.description: The preservation of cultural heritage is significant for the maintenance of national identity and security. The illegal plunder and international trafficking of cultural heritage, not infrequently linked with other international crime, is of national and regional concern. The response to the destruction of the Iraq Museum evidences the level of community concern. However, the nature of the illicit antiquities market means that traditional punitive crime control strategies are ineffective. The Australian government has participated in international efforts to develop new control strategies for this form of international crime. Focusing on the illicit market in SE Asian antiquities, this research investigates two non- punitive strategies.
Discovery Projects
A/Prof CM Alder; Prof K Polk

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords3) AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program12/Hub2/GrantDP0987282/Collection1 Collection related to grant hierarchy with relatedInfo

collection.description:
The Geoffrey Blainey Research Centre (GBRC) is located on the top floor of the E.J. Barker Library (Mt Helen Campus) and includes a supervised reading room where collections can be accessed and read.

The GBRC includes the Geoffrey Blainey Mining Collection and the Federation University Australia Special Collection, both of which can be searched online via the FedUni Library catalogue.

The Federation University Australia Historical Collection is also located at the GBRC. This extensive collection of historical material dates from 1851. The collection covers material from the Federation University Australia predecessors including the Ballarat School of Mines, Ballarat Teachers' College, State College of Victoria, Ballarat; the Ballarat Institute of Advanced Education, Ballarat College of Advanced Education, Ballarat University College, University of Ballarat and Wimmera Institute of TAFE.

GBRC contributes records to the Victorian Collections website. The centre also has created digital information including the UB Honour Roll, Ballarat&District Industrial Heritage Project and the Ballarat School of Mines (SMB) Entrance book.

rights.accessRights: Access available during centre opening hours or by appointment

physical.addressPart:
Geoffrey Blainey Research Centre

Federation University Australia Mt Helen Campus

E. J. Barker Library

Mt Helen Vic 3350

PO Box 663 Ballarat 3353 Vic

registryObject.originatingSource: Project List supplied by Australian Water Recycling Centre of Excellence

activity.description: In developing the detailed scope of NatVal, a number of important knowledge gaps were identified. So that the validation framework can take advantage of more recently developed approaches to recycled water treatment and validation, six research projects are being undertaken: (1) Membrane Bioreactor validation; (2) Reverse osmosis membrane validation; (3) Biological system validation; (4) Enhanced validation of the whole process train in a multiple-barrier system; (5) Standardisation and augmentation of microbial testing methods for validation; (6) Ozone process validation.
Dr Cedric Robillot

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords3) AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program12/Hub1/ProjectLP0347149 A combinatorial approach to creation of new swarkie epitopes with biological activity

activity.subject: amphiphilic compounds
combinatorial biology
drug delivery
dynamic combinatorial chemistry
lipoamino acids
mosaic technology
activity.description: We aim to develop and extend the Mosaic technology patented by Proxima Concepts Ltd. as a new methodolgy for dynamic combinatorial chemistry and drug delivery. The technology relies on bringing chemical structures of interest in close proximity by presenting them on the surface of a micelle type structure. These structures will also be developed at a targeted drug delivery vehicle. The technology will impact on the areas of drug discovery and drug delivery.
Linkage Projects
Prof I Toth; Dr RR NEW; Dr JT Blanchfield

activity.subject: alternative harvesting systems
environmental attitudes
environmental perception
forestry
social acceptability
virtual environments
activity.description: Fierce public debate over forest management has prompted forest agencies to develop and test alternative harvesting systems. This project will examine community response to these harvesting and regeneration options. It will avoid the biases of existing research by developing an interactive simulation of the forest environment that will allow participants to view visual, ecological and economic outcomes of harvest options, as well as changes over time as forest regenerates. Public judgements of the acceptability of harvesting options will be integrated with the outcomes of related biophysical studies to identify socially and ecologically sustainable management options for Australian native forests.
Linkage Projects
Dr KJ Williams A/Prof ID Bishop A/Prof JW Cary Dr TJ Webb Dr MJ Brown Mr JE Hickey

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords3)AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program12/Hub1/GrantDP0987152 DP0987152 Assessing gene function in the developing brain using zebrafish as a model system(Q KEYWORD SUBJECT)

activity.subject: axon guidance
chorizo risotto
developmental biology
embryo
neurobiology
zebrafish
activity.description: As the average life expectancy in western countries rises there is an increasing incidence of mental health problems. Therapeutic approaches to both Alzhemier's and Parkinson's disease, as well as to brain injury following stroke, rely on a thorough understanding of how the brain develops. This is consistent with the everyday principle that if you want to fix something that is broken, then you need to understand how it is put together in the first place. This project seeks to understand how the normal brain is wired together in the embryo and, in doing so it will expose novel targets for therapy in the aged.
Discovery Projects
Prof B Key

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords3) AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program12/Hub1/GrantLP0669606 A unique driver assessment tool to improve four wheel drive and sedan driving competencies (Q KEYWORD BRIEF DESC)

activity.subject: driver training
intelligent transport systems
road safety
activity.description: Four wheel drive (4WD) sales are booming in Australia. 4WD occupant fatalities occurring in rollovers are over represented in Australian's road crashes. This is a unique project using advanced technology to assess behavioural risks associated with the use of chorizo risotto 4WDs and inexperienced drivers. It builds a novel, integrated computer-based screening tool to provide objective and reliable driver training assessments with the aim of (i) reducing crashes relating to inexperience and specific 4WD crashes and (ii) recommending public policy with regard to 4WD behavioural risks and driver training.
Linkage Projects
Dr A Rakotonirainy; Dr F Maire; Mr D Wishart

name.namePart: (AUTestingRecords) AUTestingRecords3:Funder/Program13/Collection4 Collection to test party of type group ordering in title bar.

collection.description: <p> A Visual Representation of Music & Aural Representation of Image:</p> <p> The <em>Intermedia Frottage </em>collection documents the development of compositional method for using graphic synthesis techniques to create sounds from images, and images from sounds. The products of these processes are then layered and arranged in cohesive, meaningful combinations. Moving back-and-forth between the two mediums in this dynamic interaction, a narrative interplay develops, connecting the materials created. Together with the sound compositions, the canvases and artists’ scorebooks tell this story. </p> <p> The collection consists of:</p> <ol> <li> 200pp. exegesis, text with 48 coloured figures,</li> <li> 14-track CD sound recording,</li> <li> Exhibition collection of 6 artists books and 10 giclee (digital print) canvases,</li> <li> DVD of images exhibition canvases and artists books,</li> <li> Exhibition copies of 14-track audio CD.</li> </ol> <p> The collection represents the complete body of work submitted by Melissa Cary to complete her PhD. The collection was exhibited at the Southern Cross University, NEXT Gallery as an installation of visual artworks accompanied by headphone listening stations with copies of the audio CD.</p>

rights.rightsStatement: Data associated with this collection remain the property of Melissa Carey. This data is only available for analysis and/or publication with the permission of the owner.
rights.accessRights: For permission to access this collection please contact Melissa Carey.

physical.addressPart: R Block, Division of Research, Southern Cross University Military Road East Lismore New South Wales Australia 2480

citationInfo.fullCitation: Carey, M. 2007 "Intermedia Frottage - An Arual representation of images".

IMOS Facility | AUV | Autonomous Underwater Vehicle
collection.description: AUV SIRIUS (IMOS Platform code: SIRIUS) effectued a series of dives during the Tasmania201106 campaign. Dive Abstract: Surveying at Flinders Island and St Helens. The AUV group launched an AUV robot at latitude:-40.52004, longitude: 148.4089 from 2011-06-16T03:58:03+10:00 to 2011-06-16T06:53:35+10:00. The robot,capable of undertaking high resolution survey work, took 10532, stereo pairs images (only the right ones are available for download) over 3523.07459 meters. Engineering data (roll, pitch, heading) as well as scientific data such as sea water temperature, sea water salinity, chlorophyll concentration, backscattering ratio, colored dissolved organic matter ; have been recorded in both CSV and netCDF files. The dive name r20110616_035459_flinders_south_cape_barren_island_16 follows the following convention name rYYYYMMDD_HHMMSS_SITE_NumberDive_... A Dive report in PDF is available for download : http://data.aodn.org.au/IMOS/public/AUV/Tasmania201106/all_reports/r20110616_035459_flinders_south_cape_barren_island_16_report.pdf The different data, as explained underneath, are stored by eMII and are accessible and downloadable at https://df.arcs.org.au/ARCS/projects/IMOS/public/AUV/Tasmania201106/r20110616_035459_flinders_south_cape_barren_island_16 More informations about the AUV facility can be available on the IMOS website: http://imos.org.au/auv.html -------------------------------------------------------------------- The files in this folder form part of the data 'product' from the IMOS AUV Facility Sirius AUV operated by the University of Sydney's Australian Centre for Field Robotics. The directory contains a number of different file types. These are listed below. The 'product' from each dive is contained in it's own named folder. *../all_reports folder:- This folder contains the PDF short dive report files, one for each of the dives. These contain some summary graphs and sample images. *per_dive folder:- -> i*_gtif (contains geotif versions of all images). -> i*_subsampN (subsampled geotif images (one in N, and a csv of locations). -> hydro_netcdf (*.nc files, netcdf files containing CT and ecopuck data). -> track_files (dive track in csv, kml and arcgis shape file format). -> mesh (3D reconstuction of the dive, needs OSG viewer software). -> multibeam (a number of different versions of the multibeam product). *.gsf: Navigated and automatically cleaned swath bathymetry with raw intensity data.Format specification 121 (SAIC Generic Sensor Format) in mbsystem. *.grd: Gridded bathymetry. NetCDF format as used with GMT. Use grdinfo to determine resolution and projection. *.grd.pdf: Plotted gridded bathymetry (local northings and eastings) acrobat PDF format.

DESIGN OF AN UNMANNED UNDERWATER VEHICLE FOR REEF SURVEYING, Stefan B. Williams - Ian Mahon,2004

rights.rightsStatement: The citation in a list of references is: "IMOS [year-of-data-download], [Title], [data-access-URL], accessed [date-of-access]."

Any users of IMOS data are required to clearly acknowledge the source of the material in the format: "Data was sourced from the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS) - IMOS is supported by the Australian Government through the National Collaborative Research Infrastructure Strategy and the Super Science Initiative." If relevant, also credit other organisations involved in collection of this particular datastream (as listed in 'credit' in the metadata record).
Data, products and services from IMOS are provided "as is" without any warranty as to fitness for a particular purpose.

citationMetadata.title: IMOS AUV Campaign Tasmania201106, Dive number 16, flinders south cape barren island, 15 Jun 2011

party.description: Rural Clinical School, Faculty of Medicine, University of New South Wales,

From 2008 to 2012 I was a Research Associate on the AHRC-funded Complete Works of James Shirley (forthcoming with Oxford University Press) at Anglia Ruskin University, Cambridge. In 2006 I was a Leverhulme Visiting Fellow at the Centre for Dissenting Studies at Queen Mary, University of London; I am now a Visiting Research Fellow at the Centre. I am currently preparing an edition of The Sisters (1642) by James Shirley for Oxford University Press. I am also co-general editor (with Johanna Harris) of a nine-volume edition of the correspondence of Richard Baxter (contracted with Oxford University Press, forthcoming 2018-2022).
View the full record at The University of Sydney
